awd_titl_txt: Smart regulation of thermal infrared radiation with meta-structured metal-insulator transition
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:
Infrared (IR) images are produced by IR cameras capturing thermal IR radiation from hot objects. This process has a wide range of applications in night vision, thermography, remote sensing, medical imaging, and building monitoring. Despite extensive efforts, true innovations are sought to meet the needs of the rapidly advancing modern society. IR imaging is a two-step process. Power is radiated from a hot surface and then converted to an electrical signal by an IR camera. Current efforts to improve thermal imaging sensitivity focus on improving the camera, because the radiated power is believed to be limited by a physical law that dictates the amount of IR power radiated from the object at given temperature. Consequently, the temperature sensitivity for IR imaging is limited to ~ 0.04 degree C. However, this sensitivity is not fine enough, and prevents some critical applications of IR imaging. The PI will advance IR imaging by overcoming the physical law that limits radiated power. The PI will develop a coating material that drastically boosts the radiated IR power within a selected temperature range. This will effectively amplify the effective temperature variation of the object into large variation of IR imaged temperature. As a result, the temperature sensitivity of IR imaging with a conventional camera is improved by a factor of over 15, to below 0.003 degree C. Such an improvement enables sensitive detection of weak defects in integrated circuits, early diagnosis of sub-skin tumors, and inspection of sub-surface building cracks. The coating material can also be used to implement switchable radiative cooling to cool a surface when its temperature is higher than the preset temperature. The new devices to be developed and deployed will push the boundary of thermal imaging and radiative cooling much beyond the state-of-the-arts, promising great values for potential commercialization. Integrated with the research effort, the PI also proposes an educational program that will stimulate and prepare pre-college students for careers in engineering pertaining to infrared technologies.

Technical:
The goal of this project is to demonstrate smart, previously non-existing thermal IR regulation devices for ultra-sensitive sub-surface IR imaging and switchable radiative cooling. The PI plans to accomplish the goal by re-imagining the Stefan-Boltzmann law of thermal radiation by lifting its limitation, to achieve orders of magnitude enhancement in IR imaging sensitivity. Materials with metal-insulator transition integrated with plasmonic resonance enable a large switching in thermal radiation, a property not found in any conventional materials. The metal-insulator transition is engineered with doping and plasmonic resonance to achieve unprecedented physical properties of temperature-dependent emissivity, which are the key innovations in this proposal. Tungsten-doping substantially expands the working temperature range of vanadium dioxide, while micro-patterned metaphotonic design reverses and amplifies the contrast in IR radiation across the transition. The resultant switching in surface emissivity at tunable and preset temperatures lays the materials foundation to smart regulation of thermal IR radiation: drastic enhancement in IR imaging sensitivity, and switchability in radiative cooling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The goal of this project is to innovate thermal IR technologies by lifting the limitation of the T^4 law, to achieve unprecedented control of thermal IR radiation. Materials with metal-insulator transition integrated with plasmonic resonance enable a large switching in thermal radiation, a property not found in any conventional materials. Harnessing these merits, this project seeks to demonstrate smart, previously non-existing thermal IR regulation devices.

1. Further development of temperature adaptive radiative coating. We are publishing the result (in press at Joule) and we have filed a patent.

Previously, we have demonstrated [Science 374, 1504 (2021)] a mechanically flexible TARC structure to minimize total energy consumption of residential household through the entire year.

Exclusively funded by this NSF grant, we have made exciting progress to scale up TARC. We developed a mass-producing approach to make TARC using polyethylene nanoimprinted with reuseable templates, and the resultant TARC is on the order of meters in size, with switchable thermal emission performance similar to that of the original, lithographically fabricated TARC. we will also work to bring TARC to the market. We term the new product as "Printable, Emissivity-adaptive, Albedo-optimized Covering (PEAC)".

2. We have successfully obtained a NSF I-Corps grant (NSF-2024746) to analyze the market related to the technologies related to this projects. We also won an US Air-Force STTR proposal on TARC in partnership with Advanced Cooling Technologies Inc (https://www.1-act.com/) to apply TARC to outer space objects (spacecraft, satellites, etc). These new opportunities are all catalyzed and enabled by work under this NSF grant.

3. We have developed low-loss, geometry-invariant optical waveguides with zero-index materials. The work is published in nanophotonics, 11, 4747 (2022).

4. We theoretically simulated the performance of radiative coating in outer space, which yielded very promising results. The work is published in Cell Reports Physical Science, 3, 101066 (2022). Following this work, we won a STTR grant from US Air Force to experimentally develop the space application of these coatings.

5. We engineered the metal-insulator phase transition in W-doped VO2 for a single-pixel reconstructive mid-infrared micro-spectrometer. The work is published in Optical Express, 31, 14367 (2023).

6. We discovered the critical nucleus size in the metal-insulator phase transition of VO2. The work is published in Phys. Rev. Lett, 129, 245701 (2022).

7. Partly funded and supported by this grant, we have also: discovered a giant isotope effect of thermal conduction in silicon nanowires (published in Phys. Rev. Lett. 128,085901 (2022)); wrote a review paper "Enabling Active Nanotechnologies by Phase Transition: From Electronics, Photonics to Thermotics" (published in Chemical Reviews,122, 15450 (2022)); published a paper, “Tuning of optical phonons in a-MoO3-VO2 multilayers”, ACS Applied Materials &Interfaces, 13, 48981 (2021); published a paper, “Flat Bands in Magic-Angle Bilayer Photonic Crystals at Small Twists”, Physical Review Letters, 126, 223601 (2021); and contributed to a collaborative work "Relativistic ultrafast electron diffraction at high repetition rates" (publication pending).

Broader impact

The group has filed two provisional patents on technologies developed partially under this grant, “Surface sensitization for high-resolution thermal imaging”; and “Scalable temperature adaptive radiative coating with optimized solar absorption”. The group has formed a team to commercialize these technologies. The team has recently won the Climate Action Fund from the University of California Climate Initiative, through the Center for Information Technology Research in the Interest of Society (CITRIS) and the Banatao Institute. The team has also completed Phase I of the Cradle to Commerce (C2C) program from the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

The team’s TARC technology is being used as a case study at the MBA class in UC Berkeley's Haas Business School, as well as a capstone project at the Master of Engineering degree program. The PI was also invited to give a keynote presentation on TARC at the annual CRRC (Cool Roof Rating Council) conference. He was also interviewed by the ABC7 news on TV for the work developed in this project and other related works. His group members were invited to review and comment on related work from other groups by research news media. The team is providing consultancy to the University of California for building a Climate Incubator around the Berkeley campus. A student of the team also volunteered in the local Biotech Connection Bay Area (BCBA). BCBA is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization led by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Summary

In summary, the PI and his group have utilized this NSF grant to (1) generate exciting new technologies that are on the way toward real-world commercialization, (2) develop new IPs and patents, and win new grants based on related works, (3) create new knowledge related to the basic science of phase transition in oxide materials, and (4) broadly impact the society with TV interviews, conference talks, publications, outreach and services to local communities and professional societies.
